sub_topic: Show that every group of order 27 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C27 or the non-abelian group of order 27.
message_1: How many subgroups of order 3 does a group of order 27 have? Is the group abelian? If yes, prove that it is isomorphic to the cyclic group C27. If not, prove that it is isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 27.
message_2:
Let G be a group of order 27. Since 27 = 3^3, by Sylow's Theorem, the number of Sylow 3-subgroups of G, denoted by n_3, satisfies:

1. n_3 ≡ 1 (mod 3)
2. n_3 divides 27

The only possibilities for n_3 are 1 and 3. If n_3 = 1, then there is only one Sylow 3-subgroup, which is normal in G. If n_3 = 3, then there are three distinct Sylow 3-subgroups of order 3.

Now, let's determine if G is abelian or not. By the Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups, if G is abelian, it must be isomorphic to one of the following groups:

1. C_27 (cyclic group of order 27)
2. C_9 × C_3 (direct product of a cyclic group of order 9 and a cyclic group of order 3)
3. C_3 × C_3 × C_3 (direct product of three cyclic groups of order 3)

Case 1: G is isomorphic to C_27.
In this case, G is cyclic, and there is only one subgroup of order 3, which is generated by an element of order 3. So, there is only one subgroup of order 3.

Case 2: G is isomorphic to C_9 × C_3.
In this case, there are three subgroups of order 3: one generated by an element of order 3 in the C_9 component, and two generated by elements of order 3 in the C_3 component. So, there are three subgroups of order 3.

Case 3: G is isomorphic to C_3 × C_3 × C_3.
In this case, there are 26 non-identity elements in G. Each non-identity element generates a subgroup of order 3. Since each subgroup of order 3 has two non-identity elements, there are 26/2 = 13 subgroups of order 3.

Since we know that there are either 1 or 3 subgroups of order 3, we can eliminate Case 3. Thus, G must be abelian and isomorphic to either C_27 or C_9 × C_3.

If G has only one subgroup of order 3, then G is isomorphic to C_27. If G has three subgroups of order 3, then G is isomorphic to C_9 × C_3. In either case, G is an abelian group.
